threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

At least Ancient Greeks were monogamous. Ancient Romans were polygamous.

> Under the Romans, polygamy was legal until the Christians gained control in the reign of Constantine. The first Roman law forbidding polygamy was by that emperor made in 320 AD, stating: "No married man may have a concubine during the existence of his marriage." In this law the term "concubine" refers to wife by usus, not to a slave. Usus normally required a written legal contract and the wife was a legal, freeborn wife. In Roman society a usus wife was just as legal as the primary wife. Originally, Romans had several different grades of wife and it was common for wealthy men to have all grades. This gradually devolved into having a primary wife and various usus wives. This does not include sex with slaves who were not considered any kind of wife. Roman law provided for what we now call "common law" wives, meaning automatic usus status even without a contract if the woman slept in the man's house for over one year. The Twelve Tables specifically states the terms of this law as follows:

> "If a wife should sleep for three nights in a year out of her husband's house, she should not be subject to his paternal power."

> Thus any woman could escape being an automatic wife by claiming she slept for three nights outside of the house. Note that any usus wife, contract or not, would be considered materfamilias (primary wife) by the law if she was the only wife of a man.

threads.com: What are the best books about these? Do you think a miniseries could ever do it justice or would it just become noble savage vs demonic spaniards? were they actually noble savages? how much of the wikipedia is spanish propaganda lies, because it reads like a fanfic.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14195443
>What are the best books about these?
Honestly? anything compiled first-hand accounts, but many have never been translated from Spanish. this board doesn't read anyway
>Do you think a miniseries could ever do it justice or would it just become noble savage vs demonic spaniards?
There have been a few adaptations that are as close to an already nearly mythologized event as can be. The most recent one a few years ago is "Hernan", which was a television film split into parts. it's pretty good in telling the general tale in chronological order. As much as Apocalypto gets shat on for being anachronistic, it's still a great film that uses many native speakers of Mayan languages that still exist today. Another film I'd consider culturally significant for this reason is Return to Mictlan (1990). It is entirely in Nahuatl.
>were they actually noble savages?
I think that they were a product of the pressures put on any Bronze civilization and their society mirrored many of those found in Eurasia around the same stage of development. I don't think there's anything inherently noble about them, but only because there's hardly anything noble about most tribes/civilizations that ever existed.
>how much of the wikipedia is spanish propaganda lies, because it reads like a fanfic.
It's not clear-cut like people think it is. A lot of Spanish accounts are hardly so embellished that you can't pick apart obvious bullshit like the claimed numbers of sacrifices per year in a stone age society where the actual population was never recorded and is likely to always be guestimating. The codices and memoirs written by the Spanish friars still remain very reliable.

Ironically, it's mostly been under independent Mexico that a retelling of events have mythologized the history of the region into the wewuzzery that it is.

last_replies.com:
>>14196320
I’ve read her books. The Fountainhead was her best novel and the one I liked the most for pure reading, but the climax is fucking ridiculous. It’s hard to imagine a judge letting anyone get away with dynamiting property just because they gave a really good speech on philosophy. Atlas Shrugged is one of the novels that has very little to offer someone who isn’t a complete direction brain, and its climax is somehow even more ridiculous (let’s just have the entire country sit there and listen to an hours-long speech on philosophy on a hijacked broadcast!) We the Living was pretty good, but Anthem was a rip off of Zamyatin’s We.

Introduction to Objectivist Epistemology was a gigantic opaque snoozefest, Virtue of Selfishness and Capitalism: unknown ideal just read like a compilation of opinion editorials. The Art of Fiction was neat but it’s no On Writing. The Romantic Manifesto was a valiant effort but generally speaking any attempt to quantify art is doomed to fail.

Also, The Passion of Ayn Rand by Barbara Brandon was excellent and painted a complex portrait of her various eccentricities. Facets of Ayn Rand by Charles and Mary Ann Sures was far more forgiving and painted a much more sympathetic portrait of her (you know, versus the biography written by the wife of the man Rand was having an affair with) and does a good job of looking past the hype and self-promotion to paint a more down to earth portrait of her, and you see the Babushka that she was to many of her fans and admirers. A much less flattering portrait of her is Mozart Was a Red, a one act play by Murray Rothbard, which was a devastating commentary on the cult of personality that sprung up around her and how it brought out and amplified some of Rand’s worst personality traits

>>14193691
>How did a random feast become one of the biggest holidays in North America?

The feast has a lot of pull within the new England area for a long time. But since New England was declining in cultural output, segments of the population were eager to put forward a pilgrim story they felt would make them relevant in the American psyche. Ever since the mid 1700s they pushed for recognition of thanksgiving by the other states, and got their chance during the civil war. Lincoln was looking for a way to bridge the gaps between the union and confederate and adopted thanksgiving as a national holiday. Before that it thanksgiving was celebrated in many states while some southern states rejected it out of a scene of cultural pride. the holiday would expand in subsequent presidencies.

>And does it have evil genocidal origins like many Americans say?

yes and no. Less the event itself but the way its taught. It is criticized for justifying colonialist narrative and reinforce colonial power/racial structures as well as a product of 1865 ideas about american history/identity. It is taught and replicated throughout the united states as a foundational national story. But it ignores the history of pilgrim migration is situated in. Namely the violence and displacement of natives Americans in order to tall a happier American story about American values like community, family, freedom, and co-operations with others.

Its also an extreamly limited narrative, we only have two sources on the event. And the events importance was political conviniance rather than truth.
In this sense, it gives the impression to children that natives willingly gave the land, or at the very least did not mind the migration of people who would eventually create the united states. This is a message that the people in 1865 certainly wanted to believe which the pilgrims believed since they looked at its seemingly unpopulated vastness as a sign from god that it was theirs.

threads.com:
>With George Washington's decision to retire and not run for a third term, it is a mystery why Hamilton did not seek the highest office in the land himself. He was ambitious and certainly had the intellectual furnishings for the president's chair. It may well be that the stars never properly aligned for him to be considered as a presidential contender. John Adams clearly considered himself Washington's heir apparent. In addition, Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, and John Jay, the seniormost individuals in Washington's administration, were likely to follow next as future presidents. Hamilton may have also been seen as just a little too glib and controversial for a presidential run.

>Perhaps more importantly, Hamilton, a great thinker and advisor, was not a natural hands-on politician. He had a strong ideological bent and sense of moral certitude that made him unwilling to compromise. In a democracy, a leader generally knows to give the public what they want, even if that something is not necessarily good for them. Hamilton however never concealed his contempt for the common man, and he believed in promoting the policies he saw as correct regardless of whether they were popular or not. In retrospect, Thomas Jefferson's faith in the common man's ability to decide issues for himself proved more enduring as mass democracy expanded in the coming decades.
